channel.title: VeraCrypt plausible deniability encryption for Whonix users
channel.description:
I'd like to continue our discussion of VeraCrypt 'deniable' encryption for Whonix users in this new dedicated thread, instead of [url=https://forums.whonix.org/t/tails-whonix-its-doable-heres-how-can-we-offer-it-as-a-variant-like-qubes-whonix/7148/78]my other one[/url].
To summarize, the threat model under which I argue VeraCrypt's deniable encryption can effectively protect the user is the one whereby most western governments now have [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_disclosure_law]key disclosure laws[/url] that can legally force anyone in those jurisdictions to share their private data, if it's technically provable that the data is indeed meaningful (i.e. non-random) encrypted data.
Under this threat model, people in these jurisdictions no longer have the technical ability for basic privacy of the data contained on their device's OS hard drives, such as when they enter such countries at airports, unless they use a securely amnesic OS like Tails and the data is stored not on the Tails disk (because they only offer non-deniable encryption of the persistent storage at this time), but instead on a separate and deniably encrypted volume created in a manner described below.
The current Tails solution is not convenient for persistent (normal) computing, so I consider Whonix as a great central project to address this (with its persistent VM design of large virtual disk files which can themselves be placed inside a VeraCrypt volume).
[b]I will define this threat model to include the following provisos:[/b]
- The legal doctrine of 'innocent until proven guilty' is honored (meaning that no 'thought policing' takes place).
- The enemy never applies or threatens direct physical harm as a consequence of any aspect of the user's usage of VeraCrypt (no torture).
- The data is never physically accessed by the enemy while the device is turned on and the data unlocked.
- The data is not betrayed by forensic evidence of its existence such as plausible logs or other user data in a non-amnesic host OS (all of which can be forcibly decrypted under the same threat model).
- Physically intrusive forms of targeted surveillance like physical computer implants or cameras/microphones/sensors nearby do not take place.
- (This list may expand with other examples as necessary.)
In the above threat model, an effective VeraCrypt volume would have two following characteristics (or layers):
1. [b]The volume is in the form of a partitionless whole disk, or a whole disk partition.[/b] When a whole disk or whole partition contains headerless, [url=https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Plausible%20Deniability.html]signatureless[/url] VeraCrypt data, as I currently understand, it is a. technically indistinguishable from meaningless random data, and b. plausibly explainable as meaningless random data such as being a partition that was formerly a dual-boot OS and was wiped using a method that wrote random data to the whole partition, or a whole disk that similarly was wiped using such a method, which is very commonly available with tools under every common OS. [b]This first layer allows the user to effectively avoid being compelled by key disclosure laws in the first place.[/b]
2. [b]Make it a ‘hidden volume’ (instead of standard volume).[/b] This VeraCrypt option instructs you to first create a decoy 'outer volume' with a unique password which only unlocks the outer volume, followed by a 'hidden volume' inside it which also has a unique password that can only unlock the hidden volume. [url=https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Hidden%20Volume.html]"Free space on any VeraCrypt volume is always filled with random data when the volume is created and no part of the (dismounted) hidden volume can be distinguished from random data"[/url], making the hidden volume technically deniable even if the outer volume was unlocked. As such, you can provide the outer volume's key if you are forced to, and still keep your data private. [b]This second layer allows the user to satisfy key disclosure laws even if evidence proves their disk or partition isn't random.[/b]
Under this scenario:
- The enemy can't proceed further than the second layer of VeraCrypt protection, and it is very unlikely for them to break through the first layer in the first place.
- The enemy is free to operate as they currently do, but they just won't find anything meaningful on your hard drive.
- You cannot be forced to show something that the enemy has no proof of existing. Without proof it is taken that it does not exist.
- Solutions to therefore avoid the creation of plausible evidence of your data existing are paramount.
---
We still have a lot to learn and document. Here are some links for people to study (including myself):
https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Plausible%20Deniability.html https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Hidden%20Volume.html https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Security%20Requirements%20for%20Hidden%20Volumes.html https://www.veracrypt.fr/en/Security%20Requirements%20and%20Precautions.html https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2008/07/truecrypts_deni.html

item.description:
tempest via Whonix Forum:

HulaHoop:

The LUKS nuke patch has been mainlined upstream however it is unlikely the user will be able to have a chance to destroy their data (destroying evidence is a crime in many jurisdictions once they’ve been arrested). Drives are cloned before any attempt is made to interact with them for this reason.

there has also been the discussion of the fact that, depending on the type of hard drive used, it may not actually wipe the key.

Whonix

Full Disk Encryption

Full Disk Encryption, Additional Security Measures


somewhat implies this but it should be written out more explicitly.

item.title: VeraCrypt plausible deniability encryption for Whonix users
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
The current state of affairs:

  • We don’t have a host operating system yet.
  • We don’t have an amnesic host operating system yet.
  • I’ve explained my position on Tails-Whonix in its dedicated thread, so that existence wouldn’t help it either.
  • I do not recognize this being a popular request at this stage. Came up almost never previously but that could also be related to the non-existence of Whonix host operating system.

Therefore:

  • This is rather theoretic at this stage (absence of host operating system, amnesia)
  • A wiki page / discussion is welcome.
  • Please don’t expect me to write code for this or being able to convince me that this is a priority.
  • Feedback and Suggestions applies.
  • focus on Whonix core development applies.
AnonymousUser:

OK, understood. But you’re referring once more to the harm of physical torture, right?

No, also detention/punishment for non-disclosure. key disclosure laws vs deniable encryption hasn’t been tested in court yet.

Read full topic

item.title: VeraCrypt plausible deniability encryption for Whonix users
item.dc:creator: AnonymousUser
item.description:
I thus continue my replies here:

Tails-Whonix: It's doable, here's how. Can we offer it as a variant like Qubes-Whonix?

If deniable volumes are deemed a popularly requested feature to warrant the extra effort of implementing then we should be discussing plain-dmcrypt for plausible deniability for Linux instead. …

If the UX is less than the current “checkbox during install” to encrypt then it’s a no go because we are not aiming to support the ultra-specialized security wingnuts here. I find cli anything during an install unacceptable in this day and age where every installer interface is good enough and gets the job done.

It seems like it’s early days here at Whonix with the idea of encrypting your Whonix VMs for user protection under various threat models. I’m not pretending to be an expert myself, so we all have lots to learn and research.

What I will say is that many users in the Tor world are motivated to create their own VeraCrypt volumes using the existing official VC GUI program. I can see that Tails VC volume unlocking is massively faster than VC’s own unlocking though, which is good and interesting.

Tails-Whonix: It's doable, here's how. Can we offer it as a variant like Qubes-Whonix?

If you read my zulucrypt page you’d know VC is limited to 128bit keys only which won’t cut it.

Can you link me to that? I couldn’t find it. You must be referring only to zulucrypt’s implementation of VC encryption, as all of VC’s official offerings are of 256-bit keys.

@Patrick: I have now looked at https://defuse.ca/truecrypt-plausible-deniability-useless-by-game-theory.htm and I see it’s talking about the threat model of physical torture. For me and many other Tor users I interface with, this is NOT a threat model that applies to us. If we need to mention it as a warning, then OK, let’s do that and I agree it’s important - we have a lot of threat models and people to think and care about at Whonix. But it’s not the particular threat model that I’m saying VC deniability is good (and in fact critically needed) for.

Tails-Whonix: It's doable, here's how. Can we offer it as a variant like Qubes-Whonix?

Actually, I am pretty sure that there are situation in which deniable encryption can be useful for some situations. It’s just that I am at this point in time more sure that unconditional recommendations to use deniable encryption could do more harm than good. (game theoretic consideration)

OK, understood. But you’re referring once more to the harm of physical torture, right?

Read full topic
